newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil's PPB meets to decide re-election stance.
newsitem.headline: Brazil's PPB meets to decide re-election stance.

text.p: The Brazilian Progressive Party (PPB), whose votes are crucial to President Fernando Henrique Cardoso's second term plan, began a one-day convention to decide its position on the issue of re-election, a party official said.
The PPB, one of the largest parties in Congress, was likely to declare itself against re-election but would allow deputies and senators to vote as they chose on the issue, the official said.
"I think the PPB will emerge united, recommending that the party votes against re-election and leaving it up to members to vote according to their conscience," he said.
The official denied the party was split on the re-election issue.

But observers saw conflict between two PPB bigwigs Paulo Maluf, the outgoing Sao Paulo mayor who wants to stop re-election to help his own presidential plan, and Industry and Commerce Minister Francisco Dornelles, a supporter of Cardoso's re-election.

Newspaper Gazeta Mercantil on Wednesday said Maluf would not insist at the convention that the PPB oblige its members to vote against a constitutional amendment allowing re-election when it reaches the floor of the lower house in January.
But Maluf would probably seek to guarantee the PPB's total opposition to the amendment closer to the vote, the newspaper said.

The PPB, allied with the Liberal Party, has 97 members of the 513-strong Chamber of Deputies. The government needs two majorities of 308 votes each for the amendment to be approved in the lower house.
